msContents.summary: A certain Rāṇaṭhaku commmissioned this Nepalese palm-leaf manuscript from the second half of the 12th century. The exact date is now illegible. Dr. D. Wright read it as Nepāla 299, but, as argued by Petech (1984: 64), this seems to be impossible because the date would fall outside the reign of Ānandadeva (1099-1167), the king supposedly mentioned in the colophon, although the portion with his name is now almost completely broken off. Moreover, the date read by Dr. D. Wright cannot be verified, while it might be verified for the following days: Saturday, October 8th, 1149; October 4th, 1152; October 20th, 1156; October 17th, 1158; November 5th, 1166. The manuscript contains a Buddhist text called Kurukullākalpa, a ritual manual dedicated to the tantric goddess Kurukullā. The work is divided into a few chapters with various ritual instructions, including obtaining supernatural powers (siddhi). This manuscript was used in the critical edition done by the 84000 project in 2011.

msItem.title: Kurukullākalpa
msItem.incipit: [1v1] naṣṭe gate cāntarhi%te ca tantre tārodbhave yogamahāsamudre | tārārṇṇavo nāma mahādhitantro -3- [1v2] || uddhṛtya tantreṣu ca vistareṣu yogān_ prayogān_ ba%husatvahetoḥ | lokeśvaraḥ kalpam idam babhāṣe śṛṇvantu sarvve kila bodhisa-3-
msItem.explicit: [22v4] idam avocad bhagavān avalokiteśvaraḥ sā ca sarvā%vatī parṣat sadevamānuṣāsuragaruḍagandharvvaś ca loko bhagavato bhāṣitam abhyanandann iti [22v5] ||
msItem.finalRubric: [22v5] āryakurukullākalpaḥ samāptaḥ || @ || tārārṇṇava%mahāyogatantrāntaḥ pātitārodbhavād uddhṛta iti || @ ||
msItem.colophon: [22v5] ye dharmā hetuprabhavā hetu teṣāṃ [23r1] tathāgato hy avadat_| teṣāṃ ca yo niridha evaṃvādī mahāśrama%ṇaḥ || deyadharmo yaṃ pravaramahāyānayāyinaḥ paramopāsaka śrīrāṇaṭhaku [23r2] yad atra puṇyaṃ tad bhavatv ācāryopādhyāyamātapitṛpūrrvaṅga%maṃ kṛtvā sakalasatvarāseyar anuttarajñānaphalāptaya iti || samvat 2-2- [23r3] kārttikaśuklapañcamyāṃ śaniścaradine, śrīā-5- pravarddhamānavijayarājye likhitam iti

supportDesc.condition: Complete, in relatively good condition. The margins are somewhat damaged, and sometimes restored with translucent paper. Some akṣaras are thus lost.

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 60 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: One string hole, to the left of the centre, in the midde of a 2 cm-wide blank column.

handNote.desc: First Hand: Hooked Nepālākṣarā in black ink (main text).
Second hand: Hooked Nepālākṣarā in black ink (invocations after colophon).
Thir hand: Hooked Nepālākṣarā in black ink (corrections).
Fourth hand: Nepālākṣarā in black ink (additions on the front page and the back page).

list.item: On the front page, some notes in Nepālākṣarā: -4-vālokiteśvarāyaḥ; kurukulāvānaṃphatigā[1r2]vātanima, pu 2 i.
After the colophon, invocations to Kurukullā.
On the back page notes in Nepālākṣarā, mostly illegible.

item.marginalia: Occasional corrections by a later hand.

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright in 1873-6.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).

The Practice Manual of Noble Tārā Kurukullā. Āryatārākurukullākalpa
